Well, it\u2019s not that maps are actively choosing to lie to you, it\u2019s just that maps can never show you the whole truth. One such example is the relative sizes of countries."),mdx("p",null,"The True Size Of (",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"https://thetruesize.com/"}),"https://thetruesize.com/"),") is a cool web mapping application that shows how the relative sizes of countries are distorted in one of the most common maps we use (one that uses the Mercator projection). It also shows some examples of spatial data types that we will learn more about in this module. Try to use the web application to compare the size of your country with others."),mdx("p",null,mdx("img",e({parentName:"p"},{src:"/open-geodata-curriculum/images/en/kenya/module0/media/true-size-of.png",alt:"True Size Of",title:"True Size of Countries"}))),mdx("h2",e({},{id:"breakdown-of-the-concepts"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h2"},{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:-1,href:"#breakdown-of-the-concepts"}),mdx("span",e({parentName:"a"},{className:"icon icon-link"}))),"Breakdown of the concepts"),mdx("p",null,"So why is this the case? As you will learn in this module, it\u2019s difficult to represent the 3-dimensional shape of the earth on a flat sheet of paper. However, by doing so, ",mdx("strong",{parentName:"p"},"distortion")," is introduced. This distortion can be on the shape, size, direction, and distances of objects on the map. All maps have at least one of these distortions. They are next to useless for activities that require large scales or fine details (e.g. city navigation).")),mdx("p",null,"This is where maps come in. Maps remedy these two drawbacks of globes by representing the earth as a flat surface. By doing so, maps become portable and suitable for a multitude of uses. They can be classified into two:"),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("strong",{parentName:"li"},"Geographic Coordinate Reference Systems")," use degrees of latitude and longitude as coordinates to refer to position."),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("strong",{parentName:"li"},"Projected Coordinate Reference Systems")," use linear units (e.g. meters, feet, kilometers) of eastings and northings as coordinates.")),mdx("p",null,"Knowledge of coordinate reference systems is important because even if two maps (or layers) show the same area, the coordinates of the locations in those maps will be different if the CRS they use are different. "),mdx("p",null,mdx("strong",{parentName:"p"},"Take this example:")," Map A and Map B show the same area and extent. They\u2019re basically the same map. The only difference is the coordinate reference system they use. Map A uses CRS X and Map B uses CRS Y. Let\u2019s say we get the coordinate of Point 1, which is (10, 10), from Map A. If we look at the coordinate (10,10) in Map B, it\u2019s possible that Point 1 won\u2019t be there since Map B uses a different CRS. Or if you overlay the maps over each other using a common reference, the features on the two maps won\u2019t coincide. This knowledge of coordinate reference systems is important in any GIS."),mdx("p",null,"Prior to QGIS 3.X, QGIS had an option to activate what\u2019s called \u201COTF\u201D or \u201COn-The-Fly Transformation\u201D. This allows layers with different CRS to be projected on the map canvas as if they were in the same CRS. With QGIS 3.X onward, this option is the default behavior of QGIS.  QGIS also performs this action automatically for processing tasks.  This is very important because if the layers aren\u2019t in the same CRS, the results of spatial queries and processing like spatial joins, clips, etc. could be compromised. "),mdx("p",null,"You may notice that some Coordinate Reference Systems are referred to by their EPSG Code.
